head.title: With Senate Primary Over, a Gubernatorial Candidate Emerges

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New Jersey
Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Banking, Finance and Insurance

hedline.hl1: With Senate Primary Over, a Gubernatorial Candidate Emerges

abstract.p: James McGreevey, who nearly won New Jersey's 1997 governor's race and who is front-runner for next year's Democratic nomination, is all but invisible during Senate primary that bitterly divided his party along geographic lines; he hosts $3 million fund raising benefit in East Brunswick, NJ, for State Democratic Party (M)

block.p: James McGreevey, who nearly won the 1997 governor's race and who is the front-runner for next year's Democratic nomination, was all but invisible during the Senate primary that bitterly divided his party along geographic lines.

But with that contest over, and Mr. McGreevey's own political patrons triumphant -- they also backed Jon S. Corzine's Senate candidacy -- he made a splashy return to the political forefront tonight with a $3 million fund-raiser. The gala event drew hundreds of party stalwarts to the Hilton Hotel here.

James McGreevey, who nearly won the 1997 governor's race and who is the front-runner for next year's Democratic nomination, was all but invisible during the Senate primary that bitterly divided his party along geographic lines.

But with that contest over, and Mr. McGreevey's own political patrons triumphant -- they also backed Jon S. Corzine's Senate candidacy -- he made a splashy return to the political forefront tonight with a $3 million fund-raiser. The gala event drew hundreds of party stalwarts to the Hilton Hotel here.

But the evening's checks, ranging from the nominal $500-a-plate to many thousands of dollars, were written not to Mr. McGreevey's campaign account but to the Democratic State Committee. The night's haul, in fact, was a record for the state party.

Many of his supporters called the total a sign of Mr. McGreevey's credibility as a candidate. ''That's a pile of dough,'' said Robert Sommer, a lobbyist and important Democratic fund-raiser. ''And it makes it very difficult for anyone to compete with him in a primary.''
But the fact that the state party was the beneficiary spoke volumes about Mr. McGreevey's confidence that he will be its nominee again.
Mr. McGreevey's advisers said he hoped to raise $17 million for his race and that with tonight's receipts, he already had committments for more than $12 million.
Thomas P. Giblin, the party's state chairman, viewed the donations as a step toward parity with the better-financed G.O.P.
''It makes sense from the party's viewpoint to have one candidate for 2001,'' he said, adding that it was unlikely that all $3 million raised tonight would be spent this fall.
How much of it, then, could Mr. McGreevey -- theoretically, of course -- hope to see spent during his governor's race next year?
